title: Ilkeston Walk Route

images.title: Alan Murray-Rust / Osborne's Pond, Shipley Park
images.caption: Osborne's Pond, Shipley Park. Originally a feeder reservoir to the Nutbrook Canal which served the Shipley Hall collieries. Now part of Shipley Country Park.

images.title: Lynne Kirton / Japanese maple, Shipley Country Park
images.caption: Japanese maple, Shipley Country Park. A beautiful little maple providing a splash of colour amongst the oaks, beeches and sycamores on Shipley Hill.

images.title: Garth Newton / Chaucer Old Park, Ilkeston
images.caption: Chaucer Old Park, Ilkeston. The Council insist on calling the area Chaucer Old Park but local people still call it 'Illy 'Oleys which is the name derived from the hills and holes created by mineral extraction many years ago.

images.title: Erewash Canal at Ilkeston by Chris Morgan, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Erewash Canal at Ilkeston

images.title: The Durham Ox, Ilkeston by Stephen McKay, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Durham Ox

images.title: Gateway to Victoria Park, Ilkeston by Alan Murray-Rust, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Gateway to Victoria Park

images.title: Stephen McKay / Manner Floods
images.caption: Manner (or Manor) Floods is the traditional name given to a series of ponds to the west of Ilkeston - originally dug to absorb water pumped out of mine workings.

description: A walk from the Derbyshire town of Ilkeston visiting the nearby Shipley Country Park. The walk starts near the town centre where you can pick up the Centenary Way. Follow the waymarked trail west and it will link with the Nutbrook Trail. This shared cycling and walking trail runs along a dismantled railway line between Long Eaton to Heanor. Follow the path north and it will take you along the brook to Shipley Park. Here you'll find 700 acres of parkland with lakes a visitor centre, play areas, and a wildlife garden. After exploring the park the route then returns to Ilkeston on similar paths.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: The Durham Ox is the oldest Inn in Ilkeston and dates back to 1780. They serve good quality dishes and can be found at postcode DE7 8FQ. The inn is dog friendly.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: At Shipley Park you'll come very close to Mapperley Reservoir which is worth a small detour from the route if you have time. The Erewash Canal also runs through the area. You can pick up the towpath and enjoy an easy walk or cycle along this pretty waterway. Here you can visit the impressive Bennerley Viaduct. Just to the east of the town you'll find the Nottingham Canal Nature Reserve at Cossall. There's a nice trail here with lots of water loving wildlife to see. Just to the south west you'll find Dale Abbey where you can visit the ruins of the historic 12th century abbey. The 18th century Locko Park is also located in this area.

display_address: Ormiston Ilkeston Enterprise Academy, King George Avenue, Ilkeston, Erewash, Derbyshire, East Midlands, England, DE7 5HS, United Kingdom
